title: Expat tax deadline on property extended to June
text:
The Coalition has eased its planned crackdown on capital gains tax arrangements for Australian expats, extending a deadline for the sale of family homes and ending uncertainty for taxpayers overseas.

Scott Morrison announced the $581 million plan to remove CGT exemptions for Australians who sold their main residence while living and working abroad in his 2017-18 federal budget.

Facing criticism and sustained lobbying from expatriate groups and tax experts, the measures were put on hold before the May election.

The Coalition has made further changes to the plan, which could help convince Labor and Senate crossbenchers who had expressed serious concerns.

As many as 100,000 people selling previously rented homes, including beneficiaries of expats who die overseas, could lose their concession eligibility under the draft laws.

Assistant Treasurer Michael Sukkar will introduce redrafted legislation to Parliament on Wednesday, extending the deadline for property sales to June 30 next year.
description: Assistant Treasurer Michael Sukkar will introduce new legislation to remove CGT exemptions for Australians who sold their main residence while living abroad.
